Problem:
Consider a complex function scenario where \\( z(t) \\) evolves according to \\( \\frac{dz}{dt} = i\\omega z \\), with \\( \\omega \\) being a constant frequency parameter. We investigate the impact of applying a Fourier transform \\( F(z) \\) defined by \\( F(z)(\\omega) = \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty} z(t) e^{-i \\omega t} dt \\).

If \\( z(t) \\) is analyzed using Fourier transform \\( F(z) \\) at time t = 0, and then allowed to evolve under \\( \\frac{dz}{dt} = i\\omega z \\) without further intervention, will the frequency spectrum of \\( z(t) \\) at any later time t = T still be represented accurately by \\( F(z) \\)?
Explanation: The evolution \\( \\frac{dz}{dt} = i\\omega z \\) merely results in a phase shift of the function, which does not alter the frequency content. Therefore, the initial Fourier transform \\( F(z) \\) at t = 0 continues to accurately represent the frequency spectrum of \\( z(t) \\) at any other time T.
